articles.title: ‘The floodwaters come in waves': Indonesian woman turns to mangroves to fend off rising tides
articles.summary: Mdm Pasijah's house in Rejosari Senik, Central Java province, is submerged by rising sea levels. She has lived there for 35 years and has planted 15,000 mangrove trees a year to protect her house. She and her family survive by selling fish caught by her sons in the market.

articles.title: More than six months since Helene hit, residents still struggling
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated Western North Carolina six months ago. People in Ashe County are still struggling to recover from the storm's aftermath. WRAL's Willie Daniely spoke with people in the area.      Â   .

articles.title: Indonesian woman turns to mangroves to fend off rising tides
articles.author: Ajeng Dinar
articles.summary: Pasijah, 55, has lived in Rejosari Senik for 35 years. Her village on Java's northern coast was once on dry land but is now submerged by water. Her neighbours have abandoned their homes, vegetable plots and rice fields to the advancing sea. The nearest land is two kilometres away and the closest city is 19 km away. Pasijah and her family survive by selling fish caught by her sons in the nearest market.

articles.title: Pasijah's Resilience: A Battle Against Rising Seas
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Pasijah, 55, a housewife in Central Java, Indonesia, refuses to abandon the land she's nurtured despite rising sea levels. Her efforts come amid national endeavors to combat climate change-induced threats, including ambitious projects to protect Indonesia's vulnerable coastlines.

articles.title: Nebraska's High Plains Regional Climate Center shuttered amid Trump cuts
articles.author: Chris Dunker
articles.summary: The High Plains Regional Climate Center at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln was defunded by the Trump administration. The center received $1 million annually from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Agency and employed six people. It provides data that feeds into CropWatch, a tool used by farmers to help manage their fields, and the Cattle Comfort Index, used by ranchers to monitor weather-related stress on their animals.

articles.title: A practical guide on how to save the world when no one f***ing else is
articles.author: British Theatre Guide
articles.summary: The last ten years have been one of the ten hottest years on record. Nicole Latchana is performing at Tara Theatre. She shares the details and ticket info with Share: sharebutton#share on Twitter. The show is on at the Tara Theatre, which is located in downtown San Francisco.

articles.title: Renew climate action from roots
articles.author: Wanjira Mathai
articles.summary: The Road to COP30 in Belem, Brazil, is the midpoint of the Road to Climate Change Summit. Extreme weather events such as heat waves, floods and wildfires are occurring with greater frequency and severity than ever before, which demonstrates the reality of the climate crisis.

articles.title: With crab season open, Talbot watermen tracking weather and economy
articles.author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
articles.summary: Maryland's blue crab season begins. Watermen are monitoring the weather and the economy as they prepare for the blue crab harvest.    for their local watermen in Easton, Maryland, and for the state's economy as a whole. For more information, visit bluecrabseason.org.

articles.title: Climate center in NC shuts down after lapse in funding from Trump administration
articles.author: Kyle Ingram
articles.summary: The Southeast Regional Climate Center, housed at UNC-Chapel Hill, has lost its federal funding. It provides data to meteorologists, scientists and farmers in North Carolina. It's one of six such centers across the country, managed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. President Donald Trump has targeted the agency for over 1,000 job cuts.

articles.title: Heavy Rains Kill 52 in Rwanda as Flood Crisis Intensifies
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: At least 52 people have died and 107 others were injured in Rwanda during the first half of April due to disasters triggered by relentless heavy rains. 390 weather-related incidents including landslides, floods, and structural collapses were recorded between April 1 and 16. Authorities have prioritized relocating 1,600 families from vulnerable districts. 800 households have been moved to safer areas and provided temporary shelter.

articles.title: 'Be careful out there': spring migration raises bird flu concerns
articles.author: Marissa Lentz-Mcgrath
articles.summary: Mushkegowuk Council has issued a bulletin with guidelines to reduce the risk of exposure to avian influenza. Since 2022, HPAI has been detected across Ontario and North America. The responsibility for tracking bird flu outbreaks falls to government agencies, including the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

articles.title: 'Be careful out there': spring migration raises bird flu concerns
articles.author: Marissa Lentz-Mc Grath
articles.summary: Lawrence Martin, director of the lands and resources department at Mushkegowuk Council, is urging hunters to stay vigilant and take necessary precautions while hunting geese and ducks this season. Martin grew up near Moose Factory and said that bird populations experience cycles of disease when their numbers grow too large.

articles.title: NOAA passback slashes 27% of budget. Here's how it could impact you
articles.author: Brandon Girod
articles.summary: The Trump administration proposes to cut NOAA's budget by 27%, which would cut about $1.7 billion from current level of around $6 billion. NOAA's Office of Oceanic and Atmospheric Research (OAR) would get hit hard, its funding would be cut by 75%, and all of its weather and climate research labs would be closed. The programs that retained funding, like research into tornado warnings, would be moved to other parts of the organization, like the National Weather Service.

articles.title: DEP Rebuts Criticisms of REAL Land Use Regulations
articles.author: Vince Conti
articles.summary: The DEP is countering myths about its proposed Resilient environments and landscapes regulations aimed at reducing the impact of climate change. The regulations were published in the New Jersey Register on August 5, 2024. They must be adopted within a year of that date or the process of developing new climate change-based coastal land use regulations must begin again. Cape May County and other Shore areas are opposed to the regulations. The DEP claims the regulations will make development more complex and costly.

articles.title: QB Jaxson Dart, DE Mykel Williams won't be in Green Bay for draft
articles.summary: at 5 to 10 mph. Today will be sunny with a high of 82F (30223). It will be near 55F. Tomorrow at 5:10 mph. It will get to 55 F (3022 (3023, 3023.

articles.title: Indigenous Peoples feel the brunt of rising temperatures, climate policy
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: In the Northwest Territories, the climate is warming faster than most places in the world. In the subarctic and arctic reaches of the NWT, it's getting warmer faster than in most places elsewhere.    in the Arctic reaches it's already getting warmer.

articles.title: Palm Beach County Seeks Public Input for Resilience Action Plan Amid
articles.author: Source
articles.summary: Palm Beach County is developing a Resilience Action Plan to prepare its communities for climate change. The public is encouraged to help shape the county's future by providing input through a series of community workshops that aim to gather knowledge, experiences, and ideas. The consultancy firm Tetra Tech will support every aspect of the assessment and plan.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Is Changing Summer Tourism Plans
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are reshaping the way we experience summer adventures. The world of tourism is undergoing a seismic shift due to the impact of extreme heatwaves on the travel industry and weather forecast. The impact of the weather forecast on travel is impossible to ignore, whether you're a weather buff or planning your next vacation.

articles.title: NC: GOD'S PIT CREW HELPS HELENE VICTIMS
articles.summary: NORTH CAROLINA YANCEY COUNTY HELENE HURRICANE DAMAGE HELP is available for help with Hurricane Helene damage in North Carolina, Georgia, and the Carolinas. All rights reserved by KOAM News Now.   All material may not be reproduced, re-used or republished without permission.

articles.title: Small Island States Are Leading the Fight Against Climate Change
articles.author: Shafraz Rasheed
articles.summary: Small Island Developing States (SIDS) face some of the most severe threats from climate change. They are among the first to confront rising sea levels, extreme weather events, and shifting ecological patterns. SIDS have emerged as global leaders in climate advocacy, championing ambitious commitments and urgent international action. China has significantly expanded its presence in SIDS through trade, infrastructure investment, and diplomatic engagement.

articles.title: Creative resilience: Art as climate crisis communications
articles.author: Op-Ed
articles.summary: Queens is vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including severe flooding and extreme heat. Low-lying areas of Southeast Queens with high groundwater levels are particularly susceptible to flooding due to coastal storm surges and heavy rainfall. Art and theater play a crucial role in translating complex climate science into accessible and relatable narratives.

articles.title: Best Grills for 2025: Grilling Season Is Back and So Are My Top Recommendations
articles.author: James Bricknell
articles.summary: CNET uses thermocouples linked to computer software to measure internal grill temperatures. With over 30 grills tested, CNET has got this down to a tee. The data collected includes total cooking time, temperatures inside the grill and temperature inside separate pieces of meat.

articles.title: The Climate Crisis Is Finally Getting Real—11 Signs the World's Waking Up
articles.author: Devin Latham
articles.summary: For years, it felt like the world was sleepwalking straight into disaster due to climate change. Now, people are starting to respond like it matters. There's more urgency, more pressure and a growing refusal to accept delay disguised as progress. It's not perfect, but it's moving.

articles.title: Héctor Alejandro Arzate, KCUR
articles.author: Héctor Alejandro Arzate
articles.summary: The closure of four of the six Regional Climate Centers across the U.S. occurred after funding from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ran out. The Trump administration plans to propose a 25% cut to NOAA's budget next fiscal year and close the centers.

articles.title: Sea surface warming faster than expected
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Sea surface temperatures are rising 4.5 times faster since 2019 than at the end of the 1980s. The study attributes the rising sea surface temperature to increasing levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Short-term variations from El Niño, volcanic activity and solar changes add variability but do not alter the overall accelerating trend.

articles.title: Actual Data Contradicts PBS Claim That Climate Change Is Harming Senegal
articles.author: H. Sterling Burnett
articles.summary: PBS News ran a story claiming Senegal is suffering from climate change and that developed countries aren't keeping their pledges to help the country. The first claim is definitely false. Senegal's economy has experienced significant growth during the recent period of slight warming and its lifespan has improved. PBS's story focuses on the woes of Senegal's fishing industry and non-governmental organizations' (NGO) claims that the world isn't providing promised funds for climate change mitigation. There is no evidence that climate change is worsening fishing conditions or contributing to depleted fish stocks. Illegal fishing by foreign operators is a more viable cause for the woes.

articles.title: Warren Wilson and UNCA launch new programs aimed at climate change
articles.author: Larry Griffin
articles.summary: Warren Wilson College has a new master of science in applied climate studies major. UNC Asheville has new degree programs that invite students to study ways to combat the effects of climate change. UNCA's McCullough Institute has partnered with Trinity Episcopal Church and the French Broad River Garden Club for the series 'Restoring & Protecting Asheville: Science and Storytelling Show Us How'.

articles.title: CLIMATE ANXIETY: the manufactured hysteria spreading across America's urban centers and college campuses
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: 63.3% of U.S. adults are worried about global warming, according to a Yale study. The study highlights the role of politics, education, and media in shaping climate attitudes. Critics argue that climate change hysteria is being used to push a political agenda.

articles.title: What Happens If We Do Nothing? 10 Chilling Predictions from Climate Scientists
articles.author: Diana Davenport
articles.summary: Climate change isn't waiting for us to feel ready. Every year we delay action, the consequences compound. If global emissions stay high and governments continue to stall, the world we know now could be nearly unrecognizable in a matter of decades. If we do nothing, here's what scientists say we can expect.

articles.title: Carolina Hurricanes visit Valle Crucis Community Park after $100K donation
articles.author: nick.fogleman
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene damaged the Valle Crucis Community Park. Carolina Hurricanes donated $100,000 to rebuild the park. The funds will go toward playground equipment, picnic tables, benches and other essential infrastructure lost during the storm. The park offers walking trails, fishing access, birdwatching areas, and the beloved 'Playhouse Village.'

articles.title: STOSSEL: Climate myths
articles.author: John Stossel I
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres is hyping global warming risks. John Stossel is skeptical about the new U.N. Secretary-General's statement.       John Stosel is a journalist and author of "The End of Global Warming".

articles.title: California physicians: Fossil fuel companies must pay for climate damages
articles.author: Cynthia Haq
articles.summary: The Polluters Pay Climate Superfund Act would require fossil fuel companies to pay for the damage caused by greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere between 1990 and 2024. The increased frequency, intensity and scope of wildfire damage have resulted in widespread adverse health effects. January's devastating wildfires spread smoke particles that wafted hundreds of miles from the burn area, especially for children under the age of 5 and pregnant women.

articles.title: Nigeria: Stakeholders Advocate Immediate Action to Protect Nigeria's Climate Future
articles.author: Fortune Eromonsele
articles.summary: Nigeria's vulnerability to climate change is increasing. Stakeholders called for urgent, cross-sectoral action to safeguard the country's future at a one-day conversation and report presentation in Abuja on Thursday. The event brought together climate advocates, development partners, journalists, and innovators to discuss practical solutions for building a more sustainable future.

articles.title: STOSSEL: Climate myths
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is hyping global warming risks. John Stossel is annoyed by the media and politicians pushing hysterical myths about climate change and polar bears. John will cover four more myths next week in his next video.

articles.title: The areas of Pembrokeshire that could soon be underwater
articles.author: Patrick Glover
articles.summary: Climate Central has produced a map showing which areas of the UK could be underwater by 2030 based on current projections. Pembrokeshire is the worst affected area, with large parts of the town of Tenby expected to be wiped out by sea level rise.

articles.title: Europe becomes fastest-warming continent, also worst hit by floods
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: Europe is the fastest-warming continent also worst hit by floods, according to the UNICEF report.   Europe is fastest-warming continent also the worst-hit one by floods.     Â   .   e.

articles.title: Media peddles many climate myths that are easily debunked
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres hyped global warming risks and now he says, 'The era of global boiling has arrived!'    - the United Nations Secretary-General. He didn't think his hyping the risks brought him enough attention, so now he's saying it has arrived.

articles.title: 'Crucial' climate data center shuts as federal funding expires. Louisiana forecasters are concerned.
articles.author: KASEY BUBNASH
articles.summary: The Southern Regional Climate Center was shut down Thursday after its base federal funding expired. The center provides near real-time climate data to government agencies and private companies across the South. Meteorologists call the shutdown "unacceptable" and "a disaster" and stress the importance of the data.

articles.title: Climate change is not just a problem of physics but a crisis of justice
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Friederike Otto is a climate scientist who studies extreme weather. She says climate disasters result from inequality as well as fossil fuel use. She has written a new book about her research into attribution science, which she does with her team of scientists.

articles.title: Climate Change & Arsenic in Rice
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Rice is a staple food for billions worldwide, but a recent study shows that climate change could increase arsenic levels in rice. Arsenic is a carcinogen. The FDA has set a limit of 0.1mg/kg of rice intended for consumption by children.

articles.title: 'Green Energy Genocide': Allan Malcolm MacRae's controversial challenge to the climate change narrative
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: Allan Malcolm MacRae's new book, "Green Energy Genocide: The Climate Scam," challenges the foundations of the climate change narrative. He argues that the current focus on CO2 as a primary driver of climate change is misplaced. He also argues that low CO2 levels pose a greater threat to life on Earth than high levels. He advocates for a return to reliable, dispatchable energy sources and a reevaluation of environmental priorities.

articles.title: New study makes alarming prediction about disaster risk in major cities: 'Potential strategies could be directly applied'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: By the year 2100, outdoor fires could increase by 22.2% and vehicle fires by 11.6%. There will be 335,000 fire-related deaths and 1.1 million fires-related injuries between 2020 and 2100 across all cities in the study. Last year was the hottest on record.

articles.title: Planning Department to hold Kauai Climate Adaptation and Action Plan open houses
articles.author: The Garden Island
articles.summary: The Department of Planning released the public draft of the Kauai Climate Adaptation and Action Plan and invites the public to attend open house events held throughout May at multiple locations. The plan is an action-driven plan with 79 strategies to prepare for climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: Europe becomes fastest-warming continent, 30% of river network hit by floods
articles.summary: Europe has become the fastest-warming continent on the globe due to climate change. Flooding has killed over 335 people and affected more than 4,10,000. Western Europe remains the hardest hit region with 10 wettest years on record since 1950. Southern Europe had the longest heat wave on record for 13 days, Scandinavia's glaciers shrank at the highest rates on record, and heat stress increased across the continent.

articles.title: Europe becomes fastest-warming continent, 30% of river network hit by floods
articles.author: India Today Environment Desk
articles.summary: Europe has become the fastest-warming continent on the globe due to climate change. Flooding has killed over 335 people and affected more than 4,10,000 people since 2013. Western Europe remains the hardest hit region with 10 wettest years on record since 1950. Southern Europe had the longest heat wave on record for 13 days, Scandinavia's glaciers shrank at the highest rates on record, and heat stress increased across Europe.

articles.title: Climate change to be a ‘major' issue in the election
articles.summary: Steve Price claims the issue of climate change is a 'major point of difference' between Labor and the Coalition. A Climate Council this week made 'inflammatory claims' that felt the need to 'exaggerate and get hysterical'. 'Average Australians are waking up to these panic merchants and doomsayers'

articles.title: COMMENTARY: Myths about climate change persist
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres hyped global warming risks and now he says, "The era of global boiling has arrived".    He doesn't seem to get enough attention.      .   i   in this case.

articles.title: UAE Joins Arab Ministers Meeting on Climate Challenges in Cairo
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: The United Arab Emirates participated in the meeting of the Council of Arab Ministers on meteorology and climate in Cairo. The Arab region has incurred economic losses estimated at about $60 billion as a result of droughts, earthquakes, and floods, along with significant human losses.

articles.title: 5,119 Nasarawa rice farmers adopt climate-smart tech for improved yields
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: No fewer than 5,119 rice farmers in Nasarawa state have adopted climate-smart technologies in response to climate change impacting food security in Nigeria. Click here to read the full news article.   Â. Â   y

articles.title: New study reveals fear for future generations due to climate change
articles.author: Staff Writer
articles.summary: Ipsos polled over 1,000 people in 32 countries about their concerns about climate change and the future of the planet. The Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore and Japan are the most concerned about the impact of climate change on their countries. Most APEC nations expect their government to tackle climate change.

articles.title: Australia opposition leader clarifies he believes in climate change after debate
articles.author: BBC
articles.summary: Peter Dutton has clarified that he believes in climate change. He made the comments during an election debate on Wednesday night. He had previously said that flooding and natural disasters were 'part of the history of our state of this country'. The comments generated outrage from climate groups and mockery from Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

articles.title: Will Australia go nuclear? Voters will soon decide
articles.author: Tim Daiss
articles.summary: Tim Daiss has been an energy markets, sustainability and geopolitical journalist and analyst in the Asia-Pacific region for the past 15 years. Australia is feeling the negative effects of Donald Trump's new tariffs and energy prices continue to spike. Voters go to the polls on May 3 in a federal election expected to be a tight race.

articles.title: Commentary: Tackling climate change must be job no.1
articles.author: Susan Bass
articles.summary: 2024 was the warmest year since temperatures began being recorded in 1880. In the U.S. alone there were 27 climate and weather events that resulted in at least a billion dollars in damages, second only to 2023 with 28 such events. The Trump administration is cutting federal agencies and programs.

articles.title: Stakeholders harp on data to tackle climate change
articles.author: Chuks Oyema-Aziken
articles.summary: Stakeholders want adequate information to enable relevant managers tackle the impacts of climate change in the country. The call was made at the presentation of the Nigeria Climate Impact Outlook organized by the Nigerian Climate Innovation Centre (NCIC) in collaboration with key partners. The presentation took place in Lagos.

articles.title: Economic winds of change, but sunny skies shine down on Cork
articles.summary: The winter of 2024/25 was milder and drier than the long-term average. West Cork had the highest average temperatures of any part of the country during the autumn of 2024. The recent month of March was also notable for being very mild, dry and sunnier than what is typical. Bookies are giving odds of a record-breaking warm April.

articles.title: Watch: Healy-Rae hoping effect of GAEC 2 will be ‘minimal'
articles.author: Agriland Media
articles.summary: GAEC 2 is a baseline requirement under the Common Agricultural Policy for the protection of carbon-rich soils. The regulation is in place for 2025 as part of the conditionality requirements for the Basic Income Support for Sustainability (BISS) scheme. Michael Healy-Rae, Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine hopes the impact of GAEC 2 on farmers will be minimal.

articles.title: Nigeria: Climate Impact Could Slash Nigeria's GDP By 55%
articles.author: Favour Ulebor
articles.summary: Nigeria's GDP per capita could decline by 55% if the country and the world continue along their current emission pathways. 70% of Nigeria's landmass could face extreme temperatures above 29°C annually. In major cities, heat index levels could soar to 51°C. Nigeria lost N2.6 trillion to floods in 2012 and another N9 billion in 2022.

articles.title: Extreme marine heatwaves tripled over past 80 years: Study
articles.author: Agency
articles.summary: The number of days each year that the world's oceans experience extreme surface heat has tripled over the past 80 years due to global warming. Global warming is responsible for almost half of the occurrence of marine heatwaves. The study also found that rising global temperatures are making extreme ocean heat events last longer and become more intense.

articles.title: Scot Gov risks more wildfires with new muirburn system, experts warn
articles.author: Ryan McDougall
articles.summary: Muirburning is the controlled burning of moorland vegetation. It takes place from October 1 to April 15 annually. The season is due to be changed to September 15 – March 31. The Scottish Government plans to implement a new licensing regime ahead of the 2025-2026 season. Rural stakeholders say the new regulations will not be in place before September 15 this year, leaving farmers and land managers without adequate time to gain a licence.

articles.title: Scottish Government risks more wildfires with new muirburn system, experts warn
articles.author: PA Media
articles.summary: Scottish Land and Estates, National Farmers Union Scotland and the Scottish Gamekeepers Association have raised concerns over a new system being introduced under the Wildlife Management and Muirburn (Scotland) Act 2024. Muirburning is the controlled burning of moorland vegetation. It takes place from October 1 to April 15. The season is due to be changed to September 15 to March 31.

articles.title: Heavy rain likely in Jammu and Kashmir, Himachal; Delhi to witness cloudy sky: IMD weather forecast
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The maximum temperature in Delhi was 40.6 degrees Celsius on Thursday. It was 3.8 degrees above normal for the day. The minimum temperature was -4 degrees Celsius, which is considered normal for this time of the year in the national capital. The day remained generally warm.

articles.title: The vegan butterfly effect
articles.author: Rebecca Libauskas People
articles.summary: The number of butterflies in the U.S. has declined by around 22% since 2000, according to a new study published in the journal Science. This dwindling number is evident in every part of the country and across many species. They say that when a butterfly flaps its wings, it can change the weather on the other side of the world.

articles.title: Coastal Model Tackles Long-Term Rising Tides
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: To protect against rising sea levels in a warming world, coastal cities follow a standard playbook with various protective infrastructure options. Future climate conditions might differ substantially from the used projections. Communities risk either overbuilding too much costly infrastructure or designing inadequate defenses. The interdisciplinary team created a model that provides decision support over time as more information becomes available.

articles.title: Climate change myths
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is hyping global warming risks. John Stossel posts a new video every Tuesday at JohnStosselcom.com. The media and environmental groups push hysterical myths about climate change and polar bears. Global coffee production has increased by 82% since the 1990s.

articles.title: Warning Scottish ministers risk more wildfires spreading with new muirburn system
articles.author: Ryan McDougall
articles.summary: Scottish Land and Estates (SLE), National Farmers Union Scotland (NFUS) and the Scottish Gamekeepers Association (SGA) have raised concerns over a new system being introduced under the Wildlife Management and Muirburn (Scotland) Act 2024. The organisations made the warning in light of the wildfires that have occurred across Scotland. Muirburning is the controlled burning of moorland vegetation, generally heather and grass.

articles.title: Cyclone weakens but makes early Good Friday coast visit
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: A tropical cyclone is weakening as it approaches communities in Australia's northwest. Residents still face significant weather impacts, however, as the cyclone weakens.    - Agence-France-Presse reports that the storm is no longer affecting the northwest.

articles.title: Shattering U.S. Climate Silence
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Americans are more likely to discuss climate change with family and friends if they feel worried or at risk, perceive society as supportive of pro-climate behaviors or see global warming depicted in the media, according to a study published in the open-access journal PLOS Climate. Only one third of Americans report discussing climate change even occasionally.

articles.title: IT SEEMS TO ME: Environmental protection: The road ahead
articles.author: David R. Welder
articles.summary: The global temperature trends predicted by the computer models of the 1980s have tracked quite well, as evidenced by billions of measured data points over decades of extensive study. The engineer is 99.9% sure that global warming is a clear and present danger to current and future generations.

articles.title: Building business resilience: How South African companies can weather climate risks
articles.author: Ashley Lechman
articles.summary: As climate change accelerates, South African businesses face growing risks from extreme weather events such as floods, droughts, and wildfires. Businesses that fail to address climate risks could lose up to 7% of their earnings by 2035. Jason Mellow, Head of Broker Distribution at Miway, outlines six steps that businesses can take to build climate resilience into their operations and minimise financial losses.

articles.title: Inculcating ICTs for climate-resilient agriculture amid climate variability
articles.author: Manan Aslam
articles.summary: Pakistan's economy is under threat from unpredictable climate fluctuations. Information and communication technologies (ICTs) have the potential to play a vital role in mitigating the impact of climate change. Pakistan can enhance its agricultural productivity, ensure food self-sufficiency and increase its ability to withstand climate change by leveraging ICTs.

articles.title: Climate Change Damage Prompts New Plymouth Call For Public Say
articles.author: New Zealand Government
articles.summary: New Plymouth District Council is working on a Climate Change Adaptation Plan for the next 10 years. Residents have a month to give their opinion on how the district deals with increasing extreme weather. New Zealand now sees unpredictable weather year-round. The district's coastline is over 100km long and it is exposed to rising seas.

articles.title: Eco guilt strikes most Americans four times a month
articles.author: Citizen Tribune
articles.summary: The average American experiences 48 days of annual 'eco guilt' per month. A survey of 2,000 Americans pinpointed the specific number of days per month that people feel that they could be doing more to help the environment. The average American feels guilty for 48 days a year.

articles.title: Nature Notes: Not all birds nest alike
articles.author: JC AMBERLYN
articles.summary: Every year birds build their nests with sticks, grass, down and other odds and ends, lay eggs and raise their broods, abandon the structure as young fledge and the nests eventually deteriorate and slowly fall apart to wind and weather. Sometimes birds build several nests, never even using all of them, while others can hardly be said to have built much of a nest at all. Doves are the worst of the lot for that.

articles.title: Economy Needs Ecology
articles.summary: Pakistan's development policies undermine the environment in the name of development. Pakistan's economy and environment are not separate concerns. Shifting toward sustainable practices will create jobs, attract international investment, and ensure long-term economic stability. The global economy is moving toward sustainability, and countries that lag behind risk being left out.

articles.title: Scientists reveal exact date Earth will face mass extinction that will wipe out humanity
articles.author: Ava Keady
articles.summary: Scientists have revealed the exact date for which the Earth will face mass extinction, wiping out humanity. It would be the first mass extinction since the dinosaurs, about 66 million years ago. Doctor Alexander Farnsworth, who led the study, said: "The outlook in the distant future appears very bleak"

articles.title: KRWG News for Friday, April 18 at 7:45 a.m.
articles.summary: Jonny Coker speaks with Dr. David Dubois, state climatologist, about how southwest communities might adapt to a changing climate.       i.e. how they might cope with the changing climate in the Southwest. i.

articles.title: Crackdown on illegal fishing boats operating near US coastline
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Both the Obama and Biden administrations treated commercial fishermen as expendable. This week, President Donald Trump will do the opposite.    .   for the first time in his presidency, he will treat fishermen as if they were expendable, as he did during the Obama administration.

articles.title: HOOD OUTDOORS: Spring shallow water action is on
articles.author: MICHAEL ACOSTA
articles.summary: Lake temperatures are rising into the upper 60s and 70s and the fish are near their most active time of the year. Water temperatures have been slow to rebound this year due to the late cool snaps, but they are rising now.    .

articles.title: ACES: The lineage of Earth Month
articles.author: ACES
articles.summary: On Saturday, many environmentally oriented organizations will participate in a 2025 Earth Day celebration in Newburyport's Market Square. April has been declared Earth Month by the U.S. government and ACES, The Alliance of Climate and Environmental Stewards, in honor of Earth Day.

articles.title: Climate change and challenges ahead
articles.author: Md Sohrab Ali
articles.summary: In 2023, global greenhouse gas emissions were 52962.9 million tCO2e. In 2024, for the first time, average temperature exceeded the limit of 1.5°C. The Paris agreement was adopted by the COP21 in Paris on December 12, 2015 and came into force on November 4, 2016. It is a legally binding international treaty that includes commitments from all countries to reduce their emissions and work together to adapt to the impact of climate change.

articles.title: Global-warming hysteria bears no resemblance to realities
articles.author: John Stossel
articles.summary: U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is hyping global warming risks. Al Gore said in 2009 that Arctic ice cap could be completely ice-free within 5 to 7 years. In fact, the ice cap has plenty of ice, even in summer. Polar bear populations have increased. Global food production has increased.

articles.title: John Stossel: Climate myths
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres is hyping global warming risks. Heartland Institute fellow Linnea Lueken says it's not happening at the catastrophic pace that they claim. Al Gore said in 2009 that the Arctic will be ice-free within 5 to 7 years, but it's been 16 years. Polar bear populations have increased. Environmental Defense Fund collected almost a quarter of a billion dollars from gullible donors.

articles.title: Saving trees
articles.author: Nabeel Badr
articles.summary: Trees absorb carbon dioxide and release oxygen. Deforestation is increasing greenhouse gas emissions, exacerbating global warming. The government needs to take immediate action and enforce strict measures to prevent illegal deforestation, writes the author.       .   i

articles.title: Creative resilience: Art as climate crisis communications
articles.author: QNS
articles.summary: Queens is increasingly vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, including severe flooding and extreme heat. It is known for both its density and for its heat and humidity. It's also known for being a hot place. It has a lot of people living there.

articles.title: Warren Wilson and UNCA launch new programs aimed at climate change
articles.author: Mountain Xpress
articles.summary: Keith McDade has been developing Warren Wilson College's new master of science in applied climate studies major since July. Since Tropical Storm Helene hit Western North Carolina, a lot has changed since Keith set out with designing the coursework. Keith believes that perspective is the thing that changed.

articles.title: Hay Fever Symptoms Are Getting Worse – But Is An Injection Really A 'Quick Fix'?
articles.author: Huffington Post
articles.summary: There is a lot of pollen in the atmosphere due to climate change. It's changing the seasonality of the pollen and the types of pollen we're exposed to. The baby animals in the surrounding parks are a good example of the effects of climate change on the environment.

articles.title: Turning trees into carbon credits for climate action
articles.author: The Manila Times
articles.summary: The Philippines is vulnerable to extreme weather events and needs effective climate mitigation strategies. Central to this effort is reforestation. The Philippines can lead the way in the global transition to a low-carbon economy. This is essential for long-term economic resilience and for safeguarding the future against the impacts of climate change.

articles.title: Global-warming hysteria bears no resemblance to realities
articles.author: The Vindicator
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres hyped global warming risks and now he says, 'The era of global boiling has arrived'. The climate is warming and we can deal with that. What annoys him is that he doesn't give enough attention to the issue.

articles.title: A practical strategy to the Global Warming Solutions Act
articles.author: Bennington Banner
articles.summary: Vermont's Global Warming Solutions Act (GWSA) is Vermont's cornerstone climate policy. In a recent op-ed, he wrote about the GWSA and Vermont's policy on climate change. He wrote that it's Vermont's "keystone climate policy".

articles.title: Northland Nature: Resident 'hoodies' return to open water
articles.author: Duluth News Tribune
articles.summary: The springtime daylight is more than 13 hours longer in mid-April than in early March. The snow melts and the ice gives way to the chilly water each springtime. The daylight is longer from 11 to 13 hours in March and 13 to 14 hours in April.

articles.title: State coastal commission to meet in Manteo April 30
articles.author: Island Free Press
articles.summary: N.C. Coastal Resources Commission will meet April 30 and May 1 at the Dare County Government Center, 954 Marshall C. Collins Drive, Manteo. The regular business meeting of the commission will be called to order at 1 p.m. on April 30.

articles.title: Your daily rice bowl could be a cancer risk: Here's what new research says
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Climate change could be resulting in higher levels of arsenic in rice. This could increase lifetime cancer and health risks for people in Asian countries by 2050, according to a new study published in The Lancet Planetary Health journal. It could also increase the incidence of heart disease, diabetes, and other non-cancer health effects.

articles.title: 'Green Energy Genocide': Allan Malcolm MacRae's controversial challenge to the climate change narrative
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: Allan Malcolm MacRae's new book, "Green Energy Genocide: The Climate Scam" challenges the foundations of the current climate scam.       .   "The book is by an engineer and Earth Sciences expert Allan Malcolm Macrae.

articles.title: Eco guilt regularly strikes most Americans
articles.author: The Banner-Press
articles.summary: The average American experiences 48 days of annual 'eco guilt' per month. A survey of 2,000 Americans pinpointed the specific number of days per month that people feel that they could be doing more to help the environment. The average American feels guilty for 48 days a year.

articles.title: Indonesia-Russia ties are friendly. Experts say that's not cause for alarm
articles.author: system
articles.summary: 70% of Australians have a very unfavourable view of Russia, but only 6% of Indonesians have the same opinion.    -      in the survey.  in Indonesia, 6% have a less negative view than in Australia.

articles.title: Roofing Educators Highlights Urgent Repairs Needed After Recent Summerville Storms
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: Storms in Summerville area have caused roofing issues. High winds have lifted shingles, while hail has caused bruising and punctures in roofing materials. These damages can lead to long-term consequences if not addressed quickly, if not treated quickly.

articles.title: New Zealand's Whakaari/White Island volcano may erupt soon, alert level raised to 3
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Volcanic activity is increasing at Whakaari/White Island. Authorities have raised the volcanic alert level to 3. GeoNet observes more frequent volcanic activity at the island.    .   i   in this case, the volcanic activity is becoming more frequent.
